articles.headline: Elections and Disinformation Are Colliding Like Never Before in 2024
articles.snippet: A wave of elections coincides with state influence operations, a surge of extremism, A.I. advances and a pullback in social media protections.
articles.abstract: A wave of elections coincides with state influence operations, a surge of extremism, A.I. advances and a pullback in social media protections.
articles.lead_paragraph: Billions of people will vote in major elections this year — around half of the global population, by some estimates — in one of the largest and most consequential democratic exercises in living memory. The results will affect how the world is run for decades to come.
articles.byline: By Tiffany Hsu, Stuart A. Thompson and Steven Lee Myers

articles.headline: After Years of Ups and Downs, Trump Is, Once Again, Live on Fox News
articles.snippet: A town hall in Iowa on Wednesday is the network’s first live interview with the former president in nearly two years, the latest twist in a long-running drama.
articles.abstract: A town hall in Iowa on Wednesday is the network’s first live interview with the former president in nearly two years, the latest twist in a long-running drama.
articles.lead_paragraph: One of television’s longest-running soap operas is about to start a new chapter.

articles.headline: Editor of The Los Angeles Times Steps Down
articles.snippet: Kevin Merida, who took over the job in 2021, said in an internal note that his last day would be on Friday.
articles.abstract: Kevin Merida, who took over the job in 2021, said in an internal note that his last day would be on Friday.
articles.lead_paragraph: When he joined The Los Angeles Times as its top editor nearly three years ago, Kevin Merida was hailed as a leader who would restore calm to a newsroom that had been buffeted by cost-cutting and corporate ownership battles.

articles.headline: The Next Front in the U.S.-China Battle Over Chips
articles.snippet: A U.S.-born chip technology called RISC-V has become critical to China’s ambitions. Washington is debating whether and how to limit the technology.
articles.abstract: A U.S.-born chip technology called RISC-V has become critical to China’s ambitions. Washington is debating whether and how to limit the technology.
articles.lead_paragraph: NASA has chosen the technology to help it land future spacecraft on unmapped planets. Meta uses the technology for artificial intelligence. Chinese engineers have turned to it to encrypt data.
articles.byline: By Don Clark and Ana Swanson

articles.headline: Mortgage Rates and Inflation Could Draw Attention to the Fed This Election
articles.snippet: The Federal Reserve is poised to cut rates in 2024 while moving away from balance sheet shrinking. Yet a key event looms in the backdrop: the election.
articles.abstract: The Federal Reserve is poised to cut rates in 2024 while moving away from balance sheet shrinking. Yet a key event looms in the backdrop: the election.
articles.lead_paragraph: This year is set to be a big one for Federal Reserve officials: They are expecting to cut interest rates several times as inflation comes down steadily, giving them a chance to dial back a two-year-long effort to cool the economy.

articles.headline: Microsoft Debates What to Do With A.I. Lab in China
articles.snippet: Amid U.S.-China tensions, the company has faced questions over whether operating an advanced research lab in Beijing is politically tenable.
articles.abstract: Amid U.S.-China tensions, the company has faced questions over whether operating an advanced research lab in Beijing is politically tenable.
articles.lead_paragraph: When Microsoft opened an advanced research lab in Beijing in 1998, it was a time of optimism about technology and China.
articles.byline: By Karen Weise, Cade Metz and David McCabe

articles.headline: How the War With Hamas Has Damaged Israel’s Tech Firms and Economy
articles.snippet: Israel’s technology sector, a key part of the economy, has been jolted by worker shortages and funding fears, which could drive a wider slowdown in 2024.
articles.abstract: Israel’s technology sector, a key part of the economy, has been jolted by worker shortages and funding fears, which could drive a wider slowdown in 2024.
articles.lead_paragraph: At 6:45 a.m. on Oct. 7, Jack Bigio, the founder of the technology company UBQ Materials, talked to his chief operating officer, who said terrorists were on his kibbutz. Other employees texted that they were hiding in safe rooms, and one said her husband had been shot in the stomach.

articles.headline: The Tech That Needs Fixing in 2024, and What Got Fixed Last Year
articles.snippet: The best tech, from universal power charging to foldable phones, solved practical problems. But the worst tech, including self-driving cars and cryptocurrency, put us in harm’s way.
articles.abstract: The best tech, from universal power charging to foldable phones, solved practical problems. But the worst tech, including self-driving cars and cryptocurrency, put us in harm’s way.
articles.lead_paragraph: Tech companies would like us to believe that their products tell a story about progress. Faster phones! Better cameras! Brighter screens! Yet despite all the improvements, there are pieces of tech that have been flawed for years.

articles.headline: Pat McAfee’s On-Air Slams of ESPN Executive Show a Network Power Shift
articles.snippet: For decades, the biggest star at ESPN was ESPN. That’s changing as it transitions from cable dominance to a much less certain streaming future.
articles.abstract: For decades, the biggest star at ESPN was ESPN. That’s changing as it transitions from cable dominance to a much less certain streaming future.
articles.lead_paragraph: As it morphs from a television company into a streaming company, ESPN is undergoing rapid transformation. But if the extraordinary events of the past week are any indication, the transformation of its corporate culture is just as seismic.

articles.headline: At World Court, Israel to Confront Accusations of Genocide
articles.snippet: Israel has categorically rejected the allegations being brought this week in the International Court of Justice by South Africa.
articles.abstract: Israel has categorically rejected the allegations being brought this week in the International Court of Justice by South Africa.
articles.lead_paragraph: The International Court of Justice, the United Nations’ highest judicial body, will begin hearings this week in a case brought by South Africa that accuses Israel of committing genocide in Gaza.
articles.byline: By Isabel Kershner and John Eligon
